name: Donnie Vincent
bio:
Explorer, biologist, conservationist, & sportsman.⁣ Founder @sicmanta 
⁣
To experience fantastic things, you have to put yourself in fantastic places.

social_posts.post_text:
For the second year in a row I had the privilege of hunting moose on the distant maple choked ridges and tamarack bogs of the great North Maine woods with Hal Blood. This year, Hal had drawn the moose tag himself (the same moose tag that I was hunting on), and shared it with his grandson Rylan, as a subpermittee (which allows Rylan to kill a moose on his tag). The 13 year old kid quickly became the highlight of the hunt.  ⁣
⁣
Here’s what I learned: don’t judge a 13 year old by his cover. Ryland was sharp, witty, funny and tough beyond his years. He always paid attention and insisted on carrying his fair share … and then some. Seeing this young man and his “papa” walking logging roads, calling, and talking about moose hunting meant as much to me as the hunt itself, if not more. Now, we both did end up killing bulls, and both on the very last afternoon of the hunt. Mine came first, and Rylan’s came while we were tracking mine.  Neither bull will squeak into the Maine record books, but that didn’t matter one bit to Rylan, and he taught me that it shouldn’t matter to me either. We camped, we told stories and laughed under light from our lanterns. We cooked meat for sandwiches in the pouring rain over a birch bark fire, killed moose, shared our emotions, carried heavy packs, and piled into the famous Grey Ghost, Hal's RamCharger, to get in and out. To top it off, we even randomly found a crisp one hundred dollar bill out there in no-man’s land.⁣
⁣
Some argue that hunting needs the recruitment of our young men and women, and it does. We simply won’t last long without a passionate push.  However, I also think our young men and women need hunting more than it needs them. Physical and mental conditioning from a real hunt is difficult to replicate and the appreciation and connection to Mother Earth is irreplaceable. The system of predator and prey is also impossible to fully understand and appreciate unless you’re out there living it. To truly care about our society is to be a steward of the land, and to accomplish that to the fullest, you must be a hunter. Yes, Rylan, Hal and I hunted well and good and I’d say we had a pretty great week.
Adak, we meet again. What better way to start off a new year than a trip north to Alaska to hunt waterfowl? Happy New Year everyone. Make the most of it.

Adak Island is about as raw and untouched of a wilderness as a man can find. The Bering Sea has a way about her that keeps visitors to a minimum but if you’re lucky enough to get here, her welcoming committee is exceptional: harbor seals, stellar sea lions, barren ground caribou and seemingly more bird species than the Amazon Jungle.⁣
⁣
I’m here to visit friends and for the ducks. Harlequins and snow squalls were the order of the day and I was lucky enough to experience plenty of both. Tomorrow is shaping up to be just as exciting.

This absolutely stunning bird is known as the emperor goose. During nesting (in the spring/summer) they can be found on the vast coastal tundra regions of northwest Alaska. Then come fall/winter they migrate south to Kodiak Island, the Alaska Peninsula, or the Aleutian Islands… the shortest migration of any species of geese in North America. Because of this, few people will ever get to see this amazing and gregarious species of waterfowl… which is the main reason that I find myself back on Adak Island today. ⁣
⁣
Each year (for the past 5 years) Alaska has held a lottery draw for nonresidents to hunt and kill and single Emperor goose. Only 25 tags are allocated and I was lucky enough to draw one of those coveted tags. ⁣
⁣
Over the past 2 days I’ve been hunting these geese while being very selective. I need to kill a mature goose and preferably a male. For me, this is truly a once in a lifetime hunt and one that I am not willing to rush. I want to spend as much time around these beautiful animals as possible.

The Pacific Eider is arguably the most difficult and dangerous duck to hunt in North America. ⁣
⁣
These robust, hearty ducks call the Bering Sea home, and trust me, this place is no joke. Every move has to be thought out and measured against the unknowns and the potential risk. The water is freezing cold and the swell can build from any direction in an instant. The wind and current coupled with jagged cliffs, submerged mountains, volcanoes and the Aleutian Trench that all contribute regularly to building disorganized waves the size of houses, which make the skipper’s job quite literally death defying.⁣
⁣
We come here to truly live our lives, to hunt, and to gather and our days here are spent in awe. This is a very special place, right down to the ducks.⁣
⁣
The Pacific Eider are mesmerizing to watch. Their “paint job” is nearly indescribable, pure beauty, and yet they thrive in the harshest of conditions just swimming along, riding the surf, feeding, loafing, and courting their deep chocolate colored hens. ⁣
⁣
These birds have been recorded diving as deep as 300 feet to feed on clams, which they will straight up crush in their bills (imagine the power that it takes to crush a clam shell). They’re as tough a bird as it gets and one of the main reasons why we leave in the dark, and maybe, risk more than we should to get close to them.

This is a rare tag to hold in one’s pocket, it’s good for one single emperor goose. You can select your bird as though you were a collector for the Bell Museum of Natural History, or hunt them like any other and "take 'em" on the wing. Either way, you're allowed to kill just one.  Likely for me, one in a lifetime. There’s also this idea of weather. The Bering Sea comes and goes as she pleases. You can’t beg, borrow, or steal a single thing from her and if she catches you flat-footed, that may be all she wrote. So, even though this is just a hunt, for just a single goose... it also has to be, for me, just right. And thankfully it was just that.   ⁣⁣⁣
⁣
Leaving the harbor in the dusky hue of shooting light we steamed towards the north entrance of the Kagalaska Straight in uncommonly gentle seas, reaching the mouth of the straight in no time at all. Once inside, however, it was a different story altogether as we drove headlong into 5 to 6 foot current waves. Twice a day the Bering Sea and Pacific Ocean play a game of tidal "tug-of-war" that moves water in ways that are hard to imagine. Still, we stuck to the plan.  ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Our hunting set-up was as pretty as I’ve ever seen: a snow laden beach of polished stones and a hedge of sea grass to hide a hunter as if Mother Nature was in on the ambush herself.  Six imposter emperor decoys “walked” the snowy shore while another half-dozen hand-carved fakes were “swimming in" to join the flock. Our cathedral was that of snowy mountains, blue sky, and enough puffy white clouds to bring a kaleidoscope of color to our new day sun. Add all of that to a sea so pristine you’d swear you were shipwrecked. This was the scene for barely a half hour before the first flock of emperors were spotted flying up the straight heading out to feed.  It didn’t take much coaxing at all and they turned to join our flock for the morning. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
As the flock came in with wings locked and low over the water, I picked out an isolated bird. He was seaside, bigger than the others and handsome as hell.  At the shot my emperor hunt was over. It was a morning fit for an emperor and also an experience I will never forget. What a week spent on Adak Island.

Peter and Kyle welcome Donnie Vincent to the podcast. Donnie's storytelling particularly when it comes to hunting and conservation is unique. He is incredibly passionate and you can see and feel that in this podcast.

Donnie talks about his early days and the influence the likes of Jack O'Connor had on him as a young boy. He shares quotes from Aldo Leopold and talks about how and why he fell in love with Dall Sheep and his drive to hunt them.

Donnie is known for saying ""Don't confuse me with being anything else other than proud. Proud to be a hunter. It's time we stop apologizing for how we get our protein. This is who we are. Unless you’re a small time rancher, small time farmer, a hunter or fishermen... you really have no idea where your food comes from. Most people don’t even think about it. Well, we think about it.”

We think you are going to enjoy hearing Donnie's perspectives on hunting and conservation in this one, including his latest heart-pounding adventure chasing the coveted Emperor Goose in Adak Island, Alaska. Enjoy.

#wildsheepforever #wssbc #wildsheepsociety #podcastsofinstagram

@joelturner_shotiq is not only a dear friend of mine, he’s the greatest archery coach on the face of the planet.⁣⁣
 ⁣⁣
Joel has been my shooting coach for over three years now and every time I visit the Shot IQ Headquarters for an archery lesson, we peel back the layers of my shot-process and shot control. Through that hard work and repetition we discover little nuances in my shot… some are good (which get blue-printed in my mind) and some are not-so-good (those I work hard to overcome).⁣⁣
 ⁣⁣
Each time I pay Joel a visit I only get better at shooting, not worse. And without a doubt, each day is finished with goals inching closer to being met. I find uncompromising marks to hit, which decisions to make, how to make them… and with that mental process comes deadly accuracy and a sincere love of shooting and of my craft. ⁣⁣
 ⁣⁣
Please, do yourself a favor… stop what you’re doing, give Joel a call, rediscover archery and fall in love with it all over again like I have.
To experience fantastic things, you have to put yourself in fantastic places.

Check out the first three minutes of my feature length documentary “𝐓𝐇𝐄 𝐎𝐓𝐇𝐄𝐑 𝐒𝐈𝐃𝐄”. What a fantastic adventure it was to produce this film. ⁣
⁣
Now available on @appletv, @amazonprime, & other streaming services. (Link in bio).

[𝐒𝐞𝐞 𝐦𝐲 𝐟𝐮𝐥𝐥 𝐰𝐡𝐢𝐭𝐞𝐭𝐚𝐢𝐥 𝐠𝐞𝐚𝐫 𝐥𝐢𝐬𝐭 𝐚𝐭 𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐤 𝐢𝐧 𝐛𝐢𝐨 @donnie_vincent] ⁣
⁣
Exploring the wilds of this earth has become the bones of my very existence. It’s who I am, plain and simple. Being an explorer, however, comes with the inherent challenges of preparation and making sure we’re always properly “geared up”. Quite frankly, the gear we choose can determine the success or failure of a hunt, or… in the most extreme of circumstances, could be the difference between life or death. With gear, I’m not talking only about being comfortable, or only about the stealth of the hunt… or even survival, but more so, I’m talking about the crossroads of all three of those aspects. ⁣
⁣
Now, this particular gear list [link in bio] focuses much more on my time spent this last fall/winter as an archery season “deer hunter” than as a lightweight mountain hunter… but still, as you’ll see in my upcoming gear list videos there is plenty of cross over. As always, if you have any questions or suggestions please comment below and I’ll do my best to respond. I’m all ears and love chatting kit.

Waterfowl hunts have long been the source of some of my greatest adventures. ⁣
 ⁣
Back in highschool, I’d always try to get home as fast as I could after class to grab my shotgun and my black Labrador retriever named Claire and head out to walk a fire break and jump a couple ponds searching for ducks. Almost every hunt we’d return with a mallard or a wood duck or two for dinner. ⁣
 ⁣
On the weekends Claire and I would get a very early start to get to our secret hunting spots in time to do a proper decoy “set up”. I honestly can’t remember if there was ever a time that my little red Ford Ranger wasn't the first vehicle in the parking lot at the refuge. We’d take a moment before heading out into the darkness… Claire would sleep with her head in my lap as I’d watch for deer crossing the road. ⁣
 ⁣
On the hunts, we both knew our jobs well. Claire would heel to me until we got in the woods (or meadow) then she’d run around like a hooligan checking back in with my headlamp every 5 minutes or so. I’d be carrying my blind bag, a box of donuts (for us to share), my Remington 870 shotgun and every mallard decoy I could afford at the time (I think I had 11 in total). We enjoyed hunting spots that only the ducks knew about. Man alive we had some spectacular mornings. Now, I’m not talking “limits”, no sir, I’m talking about everything else. Rays of sun light beaming though the oak savanna. Canada geese clucking in nearby sloughs, all while wood ducks squealed up and down the river, as they always do at first light. Powdered donuts, my best friend in the world, duck decoys, a shotgun, and a sunrise. I lived for this stuff. ⁣
 ⁣
Times have changed just a little bit since then. I’m now on my third female black Lab since Claire (Maggie May was next in line, and now I hunt with little Ellie Belly) and my duck hunts have a little more seriousness to them these days as I’m lucky enough to often find myself in far-off places. I’ve most recently been on some pretty amazing trips but like I said in the beginning, waterfowl hunting has long been the source of some of my greatest adventures… but the greatest just might have taken place years ago right there in my own “backyard”.

I’ve just spent the past 2 weeks hunting brown bears in what might be described as south central Alaska, but this state is so massive and wild that it’s hard to pinpoint Northerly, Southerly, Easterly or Westerly boundaries. Still, I was in the wilderness, in the deepest of snow, under the stars, close to bears, and far from people. It was definitely the right place to be. ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
For most of my adult life I’ve either been working in or visiting Alaska. Often times making multiple trips per year. Exhilarating landscapes, never ending adventure and wildlife just as you’ve likely imagined it. It’s an incredible part of the country filled with wonderfully adventurous people. If you want to experience fantastic things, then you must go to fantastic places and Alaska is just that. ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
This trip even had me crawling into the first bear den I’ve ever seen. The experience was a bit haunting because one truly never knows if the bear (or bears) is gone from the den. And, generally speaking, snow caves are, at best, unpredictable in nature. The den had an opening much smaller than you might imagine for an 8 1/2' boar and overall had the feeling of crawling in and under an avalanche. Picture two chambers in the shape of an hour glass with the outer chamber being made up mostly of snow and ice, with the inner “sleeping” corridor consisting of excavated alders, rock & dirt. ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
 ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
The snow portion was maybe 10’ long and 5’ wide, angling downward as you imagine a snow cave would. The inner room, deeper yet into the den, was made up mostly of an unearthed hillside and appeared to be about the size of the boar. That area was circular in nature, roughly 4' wide and 4' tall. I’m not sure if the bear could fit his entire body in that section or just up to his great grizzly hump. The snow cave even had a blue-hued skylight so that the bear would be able to monitor the increasing hours of daylight (photoperiodism) which marks the end of hibernation. ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
This was such a unique and wild experience! The whole landscape coming to life this spring left me in complete awe and I'll definitely be back to this country next spring.

Its been a good while since I’ve started this journey of learning how to become a traditional archer. I’ve been patient and dedicated while learning all that I can from great men and taking every day and hunt in stride. I’m anxious to learn but in no hurry to be considered accomplished. Today I’m in beautiful northwest Alberta, unfortunately surrounded by forest fires. Thankfully, for the people of Alberta, we’ve had two straight days of rain now. I’m here to hunt big black bears and to continue my journey with traditional archery equipment and hone my craft. I’m shooting my  @st_patrick_lake_longbows designed and built by Eric Hoff. It’s very likely the finest bow I’ve ever shot and it feels part of my story now. I’ve shot it every day since my friend @joelturner_shotiq gifted it to me in back in February. Thanks again Joel, I love it.

The very simple start to my traditional archery "journey" (as they say) happened back in 2019 when my friend @aron_snyder and I booked a baited bear hunt with Blake Shmyr out of Alberta. We chose to hunt with Blake because he has very high conservation standards for his camp, allowing only large, old boars to be hunted. This type of hunt would provide me a very predictable quarry for my first time out with traditional hunting equipment. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
However, as the story goes, we ran headlong into the C0vid nonsense, and so our plans took a backseat to politics and other people's business plans. Aron and I are both pro-vaccine, but at the very same time, we’re also anti-“guinea pig” which meant we had to wait until travel bans were lifted to get to Canada. At last, this past May that finally happened, and with my St Patrick Lake Longbow in hand, I was able to make the trip up North and meet up with Blake to hunt Alberta’s giant bears. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Black bears are remarkable creatures. Spending hours amongst them each night on this type of hunt is something that everyone needs to experience. Black bears do very well to be hunted, as long as you stick to killing old boars. They live in some of the wildest places in North America and their meat is excellent table fare (don’t let anyone try to tell you otherwise). ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
On the fifth night of my hunt I made the choice to break the hunter's "code of ethics" and took a quartering shot. I regretted it immediately. We knew that tracking the bear the following day was our best laid plan. Not ten yards beyond the shot location we found my arrow covered in blood, followed by a tremendous blood trail. But as marginal shots go, the blood soon dried up. However, with the right crew (which we had) and staying on last blood, we found our bear.⁣
⁣
I’ve hunted for a very long time and I’m proud of the decisions I've made over the years. I’m a patient man but I'm also constantly learning. Learning about the wilds, about new weapons, and about myself. As a hunter and a new traditional archer, this time, I made a mistake... but I know what I did and exactly why I did it. We fail, I fail, yet we grow better from it.
null

About a month ago I received text messages from my friends Lance Kronberger and Mark Gutsmiedl informing me that renowned pilot Jim Tweto and hunting guide Shane Reynolds had both been killed in a bush plane crash northeast of Shaktoolik, Alaska. This was heartbreaking news and since receiving those messages all I’ve been thinking about are their families and Lance’s crew. I wasn’t lucky enough to have spent more than a few moments with Shane (as we had yet to be paired in a camp together) but I've heard many stories from other hunters and guides about how great of a man he was). I was, however, very fortunate to work with Jim, who starred in our adventure film out in the wilds beyond Unalakleet called “The Other Side”. He was one of the best pilots I've ever had the pleasure to fly with and was excellent on camera. (I’ve attached a short video from some of the footage that we shot of Jim on that project). ⁣
⁣
To outsiders, operations like bush plane transport might appear to be that of just pilots and guides moving hunters from point A to point B, however, in reality, we’re truly a family of people who live to be in wild places with goals of sourcing our own lifeblood and meat ... and bush pilots like Jim Tweto make it all possible (despite the many risks that come along with the job). It's difficult to put into words what a flight into base camp represents to me and I'm forever thankful for Jim and the other pilots that have allowed me to live out my dreams of reaching these otherwise unreachable parts of the world. ⁣
⁣
Godspeed gentlemen. You will both forever be missed.

To fight a white sturgeon on hook and line is to almost know what it feels like when a fish pulls “too hard”. There is no chair to sit in and no belt to harness the rod and weight of the pull. It’s just you, your rod and reel, the river... and the fish. A real battle. Don’t be fooled by the sturgeon's take, it’s most often very subtle (I’ve seen large bullheads put up more of a fuss when they eat)…but that’s where the similarities cease.⁣⁣
 ⁣⁣
The first white sturgeon that I set the hook on was an honest 8-footer, and when I did, she rocketed out of the river (apparently she like’s long walks). It was exhilarating to see the sheer size and to feel the power behind these magnificent fish. Truly, at times, the fight was almost too much to bear. But, in the end we got her in the cradle, checked for a tag (every fish we caught, including juveniles were tagged … sans one), measured, then took a few photos until she was ready to swim away. ⁣⁣
 ⁣⁣
I know what you’re asking yourself… were we fishing or doing research? The answer is yes to both. You see, when you fish with Kevin Estrada of @sturgeonslayers , it’s all about the river system and the fish. He’s a true conservationist who keeps his finger on the pulse of the sturgeon and I’ve never met someone more in tune with their home waters. When Kevin has anglers join him, he’s still collecting data for the scientists, it’s that or he’s working on the river directly with the researchers themselves.⁣⁣
 ⁣⁣
Never in a million years could I have imagined the impact that this trip would have on me. Kneeling down in the river next to these goliath fish was a moment I’ll never forget and one that I can’t wait to experience again.

@samsoholt, the ducks, and more importantly… the habitat need our help. Sam is selflessly hiking 100 miles over 3 days to raise money for vital habitat with a goal of hitting $100k. Let’s move the needle for him. No matter the region, we need habitat restoration and protection more than ever. Please, donate what you can. Link to donate in bio (@donnie_vincent).

𝐇𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐬 𝐮𝐩. Ok, yeah… I left my all-black Wiggy’s sleeping bag in the 𝘯𝘦𝘢𝘳𝘭𝘺 all-black belly pod of Callen Davis’ Super Cub. No worries though… here’s @callenwd doing what he does best: timely, safe, and impressively accurate delivery in nearly all weather conditions. ⁣
⁣
(Also, thank our lucky stars that Hilleberg tents are as tough as it gets) #hunting #huntingalaska #caribouhunting #wilderness

⁣
[𝟏 𝐨𝐟 𝟓] 𝐀𝐥𝐚𝐬𝐤𝐚 𝐏𝐞𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐬𝐮𝐥𝐚 𝐂𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐛𝐨𝐮 𝐇𝐮𝐧𝐭 ▪️ A couple weeks ago I hitched a ride in a Super Cub (flown by the very talented bush pilots Jeremy & Callen Davis) and was dropped off in the middle of the Alaska Peninsula wilderness to spend a week there hunting caribou. ⁣
⁣
The Alaska Peninsula stretches nearly 500 miles southwest of mainland Alaska, all the way to the Aleutian Islands. Weathered and beaten by both the Bering Sea from the north and the Pacific Ocean from the south, this is one of the wildest places on planet Earth. So, naturally for me, that means it's a place I want to spend as much time as possible (because, as you know, you can’t experience fantastic things without spending time in fantastic places). ⁣
⁣
With my rifle in hand and high expectations for the days ahead, it was impossible not to smile when I was greeted by the sight of these two gorgeous stratovolcanoes known as "Pavlof" and "Pavlof Sister". These volcanoes came with a “threat score” of 95 and the chances of an eruption at the time was set at “high”. That all seemed very fitting for such a wild & wicked place … and I couldn’t have been more ready for the adventure.
𝐃𝐕 𝐒𝐈𝐆𝐍𝐀𝐓𝐔𝐑𝐄 𝐁𝐄𝐀𝐍𝐈𝐄𝐒 available now. Link in bio ➡️ @donnie_vincent

𝗪𝐡𝐢𝐭𝐞𝐭𝐚𝐢𝐥 𝐇𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐆𝐞𝐚𝐫 𝐋𝐢𝐬𝐭 | Gear for me is a sliver in time. A "best guess" plan, if you will. It’s really about answering questions. Where are you going? What are you doing? And what’s a really bad day look like there? It’s also about solving problems, trying to find shortcuts, or your way out of a pickle (which is fine provided you can do it the old-fashioned way when the chips are down). Any way you look at it, above all else, gear is most essential. And truly good gear, without all of the fluff, is hard to find. Here is a sort of video "gear list" detailing what I used throughout the fall and winter while bowhunting for whitetails in Illinois. If you have any questions or suggestions, please fire away, I’m all ears.⁣(Chapters listed below)⁣
⁣⁣
▬ Contents of this video ▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬ ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
00:00 - Intro ⁣⁣
01:10 - Base Layers ⁣⁣
06:42 - Outer Layers ⁣⁣
15:15 - Footwear⁣⁣
16:30 - Trailcam ⁣⁣
19:23 - Harness & Climbing Gear ⁣⁣
21:53 - Facepaint ⁣⁣
24:20 - Field Book⁣⁣
25:42 - Knives ⁣⁣
27:54 - Optics⁣⁣
30:38 - Treestand ⁣⁣
32:13 - Bow Accessories⁣⁣
33:50 - Bow & Arrows ⁣⁣
37:05 - Outro⁣⁣
⁣⁣
#huntinggear #gearlist #gear

[𝟐 𝐨𝐟 𝟓] 𝐀𝐥𝐚𝐬𝐤𝐚 𝐏𝐞𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐬𝐮𝐥𝐚 𝐂𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐛𝐨𝐮 𝐇𝐮𝐧𝐭 | On this trip I brought along a great new (to me) rifle from @cadexdefence [CDX-R7 SPTR], chambered in an all-new and truly best-in-class hunting caliber and cartridge (6.8 TVC) from a company in Texas called @truevelocityinc . I've been very fortunate over the last few years to have been given the opportunity to help test their new cartridge prior to its upcoming launch to the public market - and let me tell you, it's ready.  ⁣
⁣
At this point in time, I’ve now shot thousands of rounds of True Velocity’s 6.8 TVC through different bolt guns, belt-fed machine guns, bullpups, and even a @dillonaeroinc M134D Minigun (slide left for video)... and am just now wrapping up my 4th hunt with this cartridge. These are just a few of the attributes I've found through my testing: it’s 35% lighter and has superior accuracy (than the comparable brass .308), there is almost no heat transfer to the weapon’s receiver (brass is a conductor, polymer is an insulator), it has about 10% less heat transfer to the barrel and comes with way less recoil. To me, this all adds up to one incredible hunting round. ⁣
⁣
You see, True Velocity is developing a "paradigm shift" in all things ammunition and I’m absolutely in love with this company because of their mission, the people there, their patriotic values, and especially the technology they've developed over the last decade to truly give our American soldiers and allies an unfair advantage on the battlefield. Because of this, True Velocity's cartridges and revolutionary composite cases will be the only ammunition for my hunts that I emphatically trust moving forward. ⁣
⁣
To be a part of this company’s in-field development for the new 6.8 TVC feels a lot like the stories that I grew up reading in @outdoor_life Magazine from the legend himself Jack O’Connor about his testing of new loads and rifles... and for that, I'll forever be grateful to True Velocity for giving me the opportunity to be able to do things that I truly love and enjoy.
Wanted to clear some things up. My opinions have never been (nor will ever be) for sale.

𝐀𝐥𝐚𝐬𝐤𝐚 𝐏𝐞𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐬𝐮𝐥𝐚 𝐂𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐛𝐨𝐮 𝐇𝐮𝐧𝐭 [𝟑 𝐨𝐟 𝟓] | This particular day started with me, once again, waking long before my alarm (the vigor that comes from the hunt always surprises me). I slipped on my down jacket to stand outside in the darkness and just listen to the quiet and marvel at the stars and shades of black and midnight blues that paint the sky. This has become somewhat of a ritual for me, and although things seem calm now, I can't help but wonder what good and bad the day has in store while hunting in such a wild and wicked place. ⁣
⁣
My breakfast was coffee with peach cobbler and was spent with my face pressed up against the eyehole of my @mavenbuilt spotting scope. I was on several big bulls to the northeast just days prior, but still, I needed a fresh heading. There! Feeding in the shadows about four miles off were two of the handsome bulls I laid eyes on the day prior. As my excitement compounded, my mind and body was taking notes and calculating what it really means when you finally spot an animal in this country to pursue. My muscles felt strong but with each step a down payment is due and this has been a very taxing couple of days. I find myself thinking a lot about the route I'm going to take. The wrong choice could lead to a lot of trouble out here. ⁣
⁣
In the end, that choice was made easier when one of the bulls ended up in the perfect location to make a move. He was feeding at the bottom of a very large mountain basin with his harem of cows, a mere 1200ft below me on the other side of a mountain-born stream. The grasses were bright green, the sky blue and grey. It was stunning. And, for whatever reason (which only hunters may appreciate) on this day... his story just happened to cross paths with my own. ⁣
⁣
Even through the shot of the rifle, the day was quiet and calm and the bull died swiftly. Realizing he wasn’t getting up, his cows continued on their way and fed straight up and past me as if nothing even happened at all. I'm proud of my time spent in this place. I hunted well and good and it ended with a greater presence and appreciation for life (along with a bush plane full of the best meat this planet offers).

This summer I was lucky enough to be invited by @polarisorv to test drive their all-new RANGER XD 1500 off road vehicle.⁣
 ⁣
The event took place in a true western paradise known as the @threeforksranchlodge. Picture a summit of off-road writers, drivers, ranchers, hunters, and fishermen… all granted an open forum to speak and learn from the engineers who designed these machines, while at the same time doing so amongst a sprawling, mountainous working cattle ranch.⁣
 ⁣
Growing up on the east coast, ATVs and dirt bikes have always been a part of my life. In 1990, I moved to Minnesota where I was introduced to the world of snowmobiling. Each winter all of the top snowmobile racers would make their way onto Big Lake to race what I imagine was the grassroots of @snocross. In 1992, three friends of mine received snowmobiles for Christmas (an Indy 650 RXL in midnight blue, a 500 SP EFI in that flashy hot pink, and the I-500 killer 440 XCR). Selfishly, I couldn’t be more excited (that XCR was lightyears ahead of its time). I tell you this to simply state that being asked by Polaris to attend this summit was a great honor for me because I’ve been a big fan of their engineering for more than 30 years.⁣
 ⁣
Now, if you follow my work at all, you know that most of my time spent in the wilderness is powered by my own two feet to get me far off the beaten path. What you might not know is that I also own and operate a multimedia production company (@sicmanta) in which we rely heavily on off-road vehicles for our client work. Lots of camera gear and personnel needing to be transported into some still (mostly) wild country, and for that, we’ve needed a myriad of Polaris RANGERs more than not.⁣
 ⁣
I am far from an ORV expert, but I can honestly say that we put the RANGER XD 1500 through the paces. Steep inclines, off-camber downhills, water, and heavy loads. This machine could become a necessity to those who are looking to move mountains, (and one I'll be adding to our arsenal) however, the trip was also a chance for me to revisit a company that I had come to admire so very long ago... and I enjoyed every minute of it.⁣
 ⁣
#RANGERXD1500 #THINKOUTSIDE #PolarisORV

𝐀𝐥𝐚𝐬𝐤𝐚 𝐏𝐞𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐬𝐮𝐥𝐚 𝐂𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐛𝐨𝐮 𝐇𝐮𝐧𝐭 [𝟒 𝐨𝐟 𝟓] | The shot on this bull was taken at a pretty steep angle. I figured it would hit a little high, but at this distance I only made a small adjustment and squeezed the trigger so slowly that I could stop it. I didn’t hear the sound of the shot but I could hear the hollowness of rushing water nearby. The results of good aim and a lethal bullet were immediate. ⁣
⁣
In my opinion, walking up to fallen animal should come with quiet encouragement and gratitude. We really only get to make this walk a few times in our own lives and it’s indeed a cherished moment.  You’ve now acquired skin, skull, and loads of meat.  Sit and reflect for as long as you can (or at least as long to properly hone your blade if need be). Keep looking all around, take note of all the details and steal every moment that you can. ⁣
⁣
You’ll hear others say “now the work begins!”… but to me, that’s nonsense. Breaking an animal down is a delight. Yes, it’s difficult and heavy at times, but it’s a reflection of bounty.  I will say, I believe this to be the largest bodied bull I’ve ever shot (or it’s at least as big as the mountain caribou @benstourac and Lorne Stourac and I collected some years ago in the Northwest Territories)… but it’s hard to lay exact claims. Both are very fine animals.⁣
⁣
I took my time, broke him down, loaded him into my pack and lumbered him painfully up the mountainside. It was a slow process (and i had help - thanks @forrestlrowe). Two round trips (one trip in the day, and one in the dark of night) and many more miles than that to finally stand him up next to my tent back in camp. ⁣
⁣
And yet only a day later, on the beach of Canoe Bay, with caribou ribs cooking over a driftwood bonfire and caribou fat dripping into the flames… I could only faintly recall the weight of this very last bull. But indeed, he was heavy.  #caribouhunting #huntalaska #alaskahunting #alaskapeninsula

[𝟓 𝐨𝐟 𝟓] 𝐀𝐥𝐚𝐬𝐤𝐚 𝐏𝐞𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐬𝐮𝐥𝐚 𝐂𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐛𝐨𝐮 𝐇𝐮𝐧𝐭 | The end of a hunt means back to basecamp and the "final load" from the mountains means a belly pod of a super cub full of meat and a set of antlers lashed to the wing strut. The airstrip, when everyone makes it out safely, is all smiles, hugs and handshakes (and if you’re really lucky, you're even greeted with a cold beer). ⁣
⁣
Basecamp out here is a sort of time-warp. The cabins we sleep in have been here longer than many of us have even been alive... yet, here we are... walking in with new stories to tell and meeting new friends. The old photos on the walls confirm that you can accomplish a lot in just a wool flannel, trucker hat and blue jeans (it worked then and it still works now if you have your wits about you). Here in the main cabin we rise well before the sun to enjoy a hot cup of coffee, and god willing, a beautiful Alaskan sunrise. The afternoons are spent exploring. I found out that twice a day the Steller sea lions put on a heck of a show at the inlet of Canoe Bay so I had to check that out. Late evenings were spent sitting on the cabin porch listening to Adam Carlman’s guitar. Days like these are fleeting so don’t go dashing back home. ⁣
⁣
We come to Alaska to experience truly wild places, to hunt, to provide, and to live. Pilot, cook, guide, outfitter, or hunter... it doesn’t matter, come dinner time we’re all family and there’s so much to be thankful for. This was an incredible hunt spent with even more incredible people and I’ll be back next year (should Jeremy and the boys have me).

Pheasants Forever and Quail Forever are excited to announce Donnie Vincent – explorer, biologist, conservationist, and sportsman – as the featured guest and keynote speaker at the 2024 National Pheasant Fest & Quail Classic Celebration Dinner. Tickets are now available to hear Vincent’s message and attend the nation’s foremost upland hunting and conservation tradeshow coming to the Denny Sanford Premier Center in Sioux Falls on March 1-3. Link in our bio to get your tickets today.

#pheasantsforever #quailforever #pheasantfest #quailclassic

social_posts.post_text:
I recently spent a week hunting along the Missouri River in the beautiful southeast corner of South Dakota and the experience was eerily similar to the decade that I spent chasing bucks (like “Steve”) on a certain ranch nestled in The Badlands of North Dakota (some of you will know what I’m talking about).

That ranch sat on a few thousand acres that sliced alongside the Theodore Roosevelt National Park, making it feel as big and wild as Ben Cartwright’s Ponderosa Ranch. This piece of land is full of rattlesnakes, coyotes, lions, bison, muleys, whitetails, and bighorn sheep… paradise for any man that rises and falls with the sun and moon.

I would travel there in my Tacoma (that had over half a million miles on it) and then borrow the rancher’s Polaris Ranger to transport my gear to the top of the coulees. From there, I’d hoof it a good bit to “my” plateau where I’d place my tipi and stove. I could see the entire night sky from this basecamp, including the stars that I didn’t know existed, and a milky way so bright and vivid it looked like a poster you’d purchase at the Science Museum.

Flash forward to a few weeks ago and there I was in South Dakota sitting on the top of a similar plateau, peering up at those same stars. The only difference this go-around was now I had a rooftop tent on a wickedly badass Polaris ride of my own (a fantastic tool that allows me not only vital access to nearly anywhere I want to go and a way to haul my gear… but also a truly capable mobile basecamp). Oh, … and a rad film crew that flew in from California to document my hunt for a couple days. 

I live for the euphoria that comes from exploring and sourcing my own food and I truly love experiences like this where I can bring non-hunters into my world for a bit with a goal of teaching them why it is we, as outdoorsmen and women, choose to live this way. I believe there’s no better way to help someone understand something than to actually show them… so, any chance I get to introduce new people to hunting I jump at the opportunity.

You can see the full video of what they captured on my South Dakota archery hunt live now on the @polarisorv YouTube channel. 

#KeepChasingTheWild

Images from one season ago. Hunting with Flip Pallot’s self-made bow (osage orange wood, backed with blacktip reef shark skin) over the rolling hills and river bottoms of central Illinois was an honor beyond measure.  Flip has been a life long inspiration to me, watching him fish (and handle fish) will teach any hunter, fisherman or gatherer a great deal about ethics and who we’re meant to be as humans. I don’t know if it was the magic surrounding Flip’s bow or simply the many hours spent observing the whitetail’s woods but, man alive, did I see it all out there. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Now, this year, I’m hunting with a St Patrick Lake Long Bow crafted by bowyer Erik Hoff (she’s blood red in honor of Chuck Adam’s fletchings that lived atop his Easton XX75s). Unlike last season, this year it seems that my schedule and the flow of Mother Nature has been a bit off. Don’t get me wrong,  I’ve had stunning hunts and I’m learning more all the time .. but it’s been a real journey and I’m definitely going to need a little luck these last few weeks of the season.  @benchmadeknifecompany

Explorer, biologist, conservationist, & sportsman.⁣ Founder @sicmanta 
⁣
To experience fantastic things, you have to put yourself in fantastic places.
